title: Labour back snap Christmas election as MPs brace for poll showdown in Parliament
text:
The country is almost certainly heading for Christmas election after Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn swung his party behind the snap poll.

It comes as MPs prep for a showdown vote on a bill to call the contest - after blocking it three times.

But as Mr Corbyn prepared for the fight of his political life, other MPs were deciding where and if they will stand in the election.

If tonight's vote passes Parliament could be dissolved within days and Britain will be preparing for the first December election since 1923.

Boris Johnson's bill would trigger a general election on December 12 - but MPs may yet try to wrestle control of the date.

Crucially Labour have not yet explicitly confirmed that they will back the Bill, there are still wranglings over the date and Mr Corbyn faces an angry Labour revolt.

But even without Labour support, the Bill was already expected to pass due to some agreement between the Tories, Lib Dems and SNP.

If it is backed by Labour's leader, it will be almost impossible for the Bill to fail even if there is a huge Labour rebellion.

The first vote is due at 5pm, and a final vote is due at 7pm.

Dozens of Labour MPs could rebel if they are whipped to back an election. Some 38 voted directly against holding a general election last night.

And a string of prominent Tories were also furious at Boris Johnson's decision to push ahead with an election instead of trying to pass his Brexit deal in Parliament.

Heidi Allen, who was elected in 2017 as a Conservative MP before leading the ill-fated Change UK and defecting to the Liberal Democrats, has confirmed she will not stand again .

Follow the latest updates below.
description: It comes as MPs prep for a showdown vote on a bill to call the contest - after blocking it three times
